cards.title: England Under-21s pay price of riches arriving before care and experience
cards.rawTitle: England Under-21s pay price of riches arriving before care and experience

item.title: England under-21s pay price of riches arriving before care and experience
item.trailText: After Gareth Southgate’s side exited the European Under-21 Championship, Owen Hargreaves offered a reminder that other career trajectories are available to young players
item.standFirst: After Gareth Southgate’s side exited the European Under-21 Championship following a limp defeat to Italy, the presence of Owen Hargreaves offered a reminder that other career trajectories are available to young players
item.body:
When Owen Hargreaves gave his thoughtful criticisms of England’s under-21 team as they went out of the European championship on Wednesday night, it came as a reminder that the former Bayern Munich and Manchester United midfielder was arguably the last outfield player to live up to and beyond his assumed potential in an England shirt.

Related: Deficit of experience costs England Under-21s dear | John Ashdown

Widespread scepticism had greeted Hargreaves’s arrival. Born in Canada, he was the first man to play for England without having played football in Britain. Few England fans knew much about him when Sven-Goran Eriksson gave him his first cap, at 20 years of age, in 2001. Three years later it was revealed that he was the fittest member of Eriksson’s squad at the European Championship, but he still had to survive booing at the start of the ill-starred, Wag-infested 2006 World Cup campaign before the fans voted him England’s player of the tournament and of the season, a double distinction that remains unique.

There is no telling what he might have achieved had fate not dealt him a series of such vicious blows after United paid £17m for his signature in the summer of 2007. Until being permanently sidelined by a series of knee injuries, he had certainly done enough to show he was not going to be consumed by the flames of celebrity that lick at the heels of all England’s international footballers.

What made Hargreaves different was that he had not been created by the English system. He had avoided the experience of being cosseted from childhood, surrounded by agents and other sycophants, and showered with absurd amounts of money at an age when he might still have been doing a paper round. Everything he was, he made of himself. Everything he achieved he fought for against the odds, going to a foreign country at 16 and learning a new language, developing his self-reliance in a ferociously competitive environment.

Quite a contrast there with the young men who lost two of their three matches in the Czech Republic this month, and were lucky to win the other. Every one of Gareth Southgate’s players had come through English academies, and none of them – even the generally estimable Harry Kane, who did not manage a single goal in 270 minutes of play – produced anything decisive when it really counted.

This week’s failure provoked scornful references to the claim made two years ago by Greg Dyke of England’s intention to win the World Cup in 2022. The chairman of the Football Association could not be faulted for demonstrating ambition. How would his critics have reacted to an official announcement that elimination in the semi-finals would represent an acceptable performance? It is equally foolish to mock the FA’s technical director, Dan Ashworth, for promoting a scheme to get all the national teams, junior and senior, to adopt the same basic possession-based philosophy.

Keeping the ball is no guarantee of success, particularly when much of it is thrown away by slack passing, but it is a perfectly sound base from which to begin a reconstruction. Southgate’s players had the majority of possession against Sweden and Italy, and more or less parity with Portugal. What they lacked was a figure with the personality and the dynamism to break the defensive line by doing the unexpected.

There, in the question of mentality rather than technique, lies the real problem. Those young English players good enough to win a place in the academy of a top Premier League club are given too much, too soon in respect of material comforts and rewards, and not enough of whatever it takes to build their sense of responsibility and initiative.

At under-17 level, England won the European Championship in 2010 and 2014. The talent must be there. But when a top Premier League manager needs a player capable of changing a game, he looks abroad for a finished product. The effect on the attitude of young English contenders for the same position cannot be good, when they know that by sitting on the bench – if they are lucky – or by going out on loan they will still be earning every week what the average English worker is paid in a year.

So Chelsea’s Josh McEachran, the creative fulcrum of the 2010 European Under-17 Championship winners, has since been loaned to five different clubs and now, at 22, must find a way of reviving a moribund career. The 18-year-old Patrick Roberts, named in the team of the tournament in 2014, made three appearances in the Championship in the second half of last season, all as a substitute. If Fulham were to accept the £5m allegedly offered by Manchester City for his signature last week, what would the future hold for his development at a club for whom Premier League and European success is a necessity, and whose motive could be simply to fill their quota of “home-produced” players, with the possibility of profiting from a future sale?

It is a system guaranteed to produce underachievement and wasted talent. The biggest clubs are not to be blamed for stocking up with players good enough to compete at the top level in the Champions League, but they are demonstrably not doing enough to teach their young English players how to exist in the world created for them. Is there no one capable of persuading a 20-year-old senior international that inhaling laughing gas is unprofessional? Or showing a gifted 19-year-old that he is damaging his career by apparently getting wasted in Tenerife? Or even convincing a 21-year-old coming off a worryingly unsatisfactory season that circulating an apparently harmless picture of himself sitting poolside in the Balearics does not convey a good impression?

Bobby Moore and Bryan Robson liked a drink, sometimes two. But they did not have to fight their way into the West Ham or the West Brom first team through foreign team-mates hardened by Champions League and World Cup experience. The challenge today is different for young men whose rewards are completely disproportionate to their actual achievements, making the need for effective pastoral care even greater.

This is not a peripheral concern. In terms of establishing priorities, creating a sense of responsibility and encouraging good decision-making on the pitch, it is as important as the quality of the actual coaching. And since it is unlikely to be addressed, it is difficult to imagine England succeeding at anything other than the fish-in-a-barrel world of qualifying tournaments ever again.

Southgate may or may not be a good coach, but the root cause of what happened this week is far beyond his control.

cards.title: Germany 1-1 France / Germany win 5-4 on penalties to reach semis
cards.rawTitle: Germany win 5-4 on penalties to reach semis

item.title: Germany beat France in penalty shootout to reach World Cup semi-final
item.trailText: Germany beat France in a penalty shootout after their thrilling Women’s World Cup quarter-final ended 1-1 after extra-time
item.standFirst:
• Germany 1-1 France (aet; Germany win 5-4 on penalties)
• Sasic 84pen; Necib 64
item.body:
Germany beat France in a penalty shootout after their thrilling Women’s World Cup quarter-final ended 1-1 after extra-time.

The Germans triumphed 5-4 on penalties when the fifth taker for France, Claire Lavogez, saw her kick saved by the Germany goalkeeper, Nadine Angerer.

Louisa Necib had put France in front in the 64th minute but Germany equalised in the 84th when Celia Sasic converted a penalty after Amel Majri was ruled to have handled inside the box.

Germany will face the winners of Friday’s quarter-final between USA and China.

The clash between the top-ranked Germans and a French team placed third in the world was expected to be a memorable encounter and it more than lived up to the billing.

With the quality of the two teams it could easily have been the tournament final and the French will head home feeling they have missed out on a real chance to win their first World Cup.

They certainly looked like champions during a first half in which they dominated large sections of play, with some flowing attacking football that produced several good openings.

The best chance of the opening 45 minutes came almost straight from kick-off when Necib put wide from a glorious position at the back post.

Germany coach Silvia Neid made a key switch at the break bringing in Dsenifer Marozsan for Anja Mittag and the move paid off significantly.

Marozsan brought the German attack to life, forcing a good save out of Sarah Bouhaddi shortly after Sasic had tested her with a low drive.

But it was the French who grabbed the lead when Necib pounced on a poor clearance and her shot deflected off German defender Annike Krahn and curled into the corner.

France looked to be on their way into the last four but with six minutes of normal time remaining, Leonie Majer drove a cross into the box which struck Majri, who had stretched out her arm, and Sasic confidently slotted home her sixth goal of the tournament.

Both teams tired in extra-time and there were few chances created.

The Germans scored all five of their spot-kicks before goalkeeper Angerer got down well to keep out Lavogez’s attempt.

cards.title: Women’s World Cup / Spacey: England will be ready for Canada
cards.rawTitle: Spacey: England will be ready for Canada

item.title: Women’s World Cup: England will be ready for Canada, says Marieanne Spacey
item.trailText: Lionesses assistant praises the work of England head coach Mark Sampson and tells Louise Taylor female coaches can break into the men’s game
item.standFirst: Lionesses assistant praises the work of England head coach Mark Sampson and is backing female coaches to break into the men’s game
item.body:
Marieanne Spacey rolls up her sleeves and angles the chair in a prime position to make the very most of some surprisingly hot Canadian June sunshine. “We’ll get a bit of vitamin D,” says England’s assistant coach, enjoying the strong UV rays which serve as a reminder that most key cities in this vast country sit at a more southerly latitude than the United Kingdom.

Without the insulating effect of the Gulf Stream, English winters would be at least as brutally harsh as those on the North American side of the Atlantic but a relatively mild domestic climate is not the only thing the Lionesses are grateful for.

Thanks to a multimillion-pound investment from the Football Association and the pioneering work of, among others, Hope Powell and Howard Wilkinson, Mark Sampson’s squad are preparing for Saturday night’s World Cup quarter-final against Canada fully shielded from the indignities and inconveniences encountered by Spacey 20 years ago.

Back then she was the most feared female forward in England. Capable of scoring from almost anywhere beyond the halfway line, she combined pace, vision, technique and power, usually in an attacking midfield or second striker role.

Such attributes did not prevent her struggling to get time off work from her job as a fitness instructor at a leisure centre in order to star in the 1995 World Cup in Sweden. In the end she had to beg sympathetic colleagues to cover shifts the boss initially refused to release her from.

It all seems a long way from the business class flights and the series of five-star hotels in Moncton, Montreal, Ottawa and now Vancouver the class of 2015 are enjoying. On Tuesday England made the five-and-a-half-hour trip from Ottawa to Vancouver on a private plane specially chartered by Fifa. Each player had a row of three seats to themselves. In 1995 Spacey and her fellow part-timers – (the majority of Sampson’s squad are professionals earning up to £70,000 a year) – including Clare Taylor, a postal worker, and Donna Smith, a firefighter, would have marvelled at the chefs, psychologists and exercise specialists accompanying England on their journey to the edge of the Pacific.

“We had nothing like the resources the women’s team have these days,” says Spacey, now 49, who recalls the tiredness and stiffness involved in having to travel between matches on an overnight Swedish train before being eliminated by Germany in the quarter-finals.

Far from jealous of the luxury cocooning of her successors, Sampson’s right-hand woman is simply proud to be part of the legacy she helped create. “It would be churlish to begrudge this squad anything,” she says. “I’ve had my time, I loved being a player but I’ve got no hang-ups about not being 20 or 30 years younger. I just consider myself very lucky to still be involved in helping Mark.”

She hopes a by-product of potential English World Cup glory will be an increase in the number of women enrolling for the FA’s coaching courses. With her daughter, Sophie, now 19, Spacey – already a holder of the A licence – has the time needed to work towards the next and final step. She intends to secure her pro licence in the near future.

When she does, she will become only the fifth woman in England to hold European football’s gold standard qualification, something now mandatory for Premier League managers.

This dearth is partly explained by the fact that no women are included among the 40-plus intake on the FA’s current A licence course. Spacey regards this as a blip. “There’s none on the one happening now but, to put it in context, there were eight on the February course and there will be four women on the next one,” says the former Arsenal striker and Fulham manager.

There are concerns that, of the 24 coaches present at the start of Canada 2015 only eight were female but Spacey remains reasonably relaxed about an apparent disconnect. Indeed she regards it as an inevitable part of the game’s evolution and believes that, given time and patience, this imbalance will correct itself.

“It takes a long time to get to international level as a coach, you can’t just be parachuted in,” she says. “But more and more female coaches are coming through the system so, maybe by the time the next World Cup comes round it will be more like half and half.

“You just can’t say there should be X number of women in these positions. What about the best person for the job? There’s a strong argument for that. It should be the right person regardless of their sex.

“There are arguments for having women coaches in women’s football and arguments for female teams having male coaches. Mark and I have a learnt a lot from working with each other and we’re still learning.”

At 32, he is 17 years Spacey’s junior but she regards the Welshman as anything but a novice. “Mark’s very clever tactically,” she says. “He puts an awful lot of work into making sure he’s the best he can be, you see it in the way he prepares for every game.”

She can envisage a day when, an albeit limited, number of women coach male teams, with the change most likely to come at academy level where some female pioneers are already employed: “I think you’ll see them working in men’s football in the future. Initially it will probably be in academies but I think opportunities will increase for those that want to work with men.

“It takes time to work through all the various levels of qualifications you need though. You can’t rush through them. You have to put in the coaching hours. There’s no quick short-cut. For me there’s an argument for developing female coaches with younger age groups and slowly but surely bringing them up to senior level.”

The important thing is that there now exists what Spacey terms a clear pathway for those seeking to follow in the footsteps of Powell, Sampson’s predecessor. She readily acknowledges its existence is partly down to the efforts of a man.

“During Howard Wilkinson’s time as the FA’s technical director he was a real advocate for women’s football,” she says. “Howard was a real help in setting up a structure we should be proud of.

“He was a big supporter of ours. Without people like Howard and Hope we’d still be fighting to be able to pay our own way to play here in Canada. If we succeed in this tournament it will be a tribute to all the people who have worked so hard, for so long, behind the scenes.”

For now, the sky remains near cloudless as the Lionesses sip lattes at a hip urban coffee shop before taking a morning stroll down to Vancouver’s Sunset Beach. No one is more delighted to see them enjoying their moment in the sun than Spacey.

“I played in a pioneering England team but I hope this one will be a successful England,” she says. “The women’s game has made incredible strides in the last 20 years. Now we have a real chance to keep that progress going.”

cards.title: Leicester City / Japan striker Okazaki joins from Mainz
cards.rawTitle: Japan striker Okazaki joins from Mainz

item.title: Leicester City secure signing of Shinji Okazaki from Mainz
item.trailText: Leicester City have signed the Japanese striker Shinji Okazaki from Mainz, subject to a work permit and international clearance
item.standFirst:
• Japan international’s move confirmed, subject to work permit
• Shinji Okazaki has scored 43 goals in 93 games for Japan
item.body:
Leicester City have signed the Japanese striker Shinji Okazaki from Mainz, subject to a work permit and international clearance. The 29-year-old moves to the King Power Stadium for an undisclosed fee.

He becomes Leicester’s third summer signing after Robert Huth and Christian Fuchs. Okazaki has signed a four-year deal. He has scored 43 goals in 93 games for Japan and struck nine times in the Bundesliga for Mainz last season.

Okazaki told Leicester’s website: “I am very happy to be here. To play in the Premier League is my dream and I will make every effort to help the team here at Leicester City. I will do my best to show how I can play and try to make a lot of goals for the supporters.

“I watched every match [last season] in the Premier League. Not all of them are easy. There were hard games.

“In the last few games the crowd were great and the players responded. It was an amazing result at the end of the season.”

cards.title: QPR / Phillips in talks with Crystal Palace, Sunderland and West Brom
cards.rawTitle: Phillips in talks with Crystal Palace, Sunderland and West Brom

item.title: QPR’s Matt Phillips in talks with Crystal Palace, Sunderland and West Brom
item.trailText: The clubs showing an interest in Matt Phillips are aware QPR are open to offers for the winger
item.standFirst:
• Winger joined QPR from Blackpool in 2013 for £5m
• Phillips’s suitors aware QPR are open to offers
item.body:
Matt Phillips is in talks with Crystal Palace, Sunderland and West Bromwich Albion, as Queens Park Rangers look to offload him as part of sweeping changes to their squad before their return to the Championship.

The 24-year-old winger, who joined QPR from Blackpool in 2013 for £5m, finished last season strongly under the manager, Chris Ramsey.

Phillips’s suitors believe he has the quality to remain in the Premier League and they are also aware QPR are open to offers.

They intend to reduce their wage bill dramatically over the summer and they have already released a host of players, with several more returning after loan spells to their parent clubs.

sublinks.rawTitle: Keeper sacked by Leicester over racist sex film joins

item.title: Northampton sign goalkeeper sacked by Leicester City over racist sex film
item.trailText: Northampton Town have signed the sacked Leicester City goalkeeper Adam Smith on a two-year deal
item.standFirst:
• Adam Smith one of three players sacked by City over racist video
• Goalkeeper says he is ‘deeply ashamed, and desperately sorry’
item.body:
Northampton Town have signed goalkeeper Adam Smith on a two-year deal – nine days after Smith was sacked by Leicester City for taking part in a racist sex film on a post-season tour to Thailand.

City sacked three players – the others being James Pearson, the son of the club’s manager, Nigel Pearson, and Tom Hopper – following an investigation into allegations that they had racially abused and made other offensive comments to women with whom they were engaging in sex acts in a Thai hotel room.

Among the allegations was that a player had called one of the women a “slit eye”. The video was alleged to have later been shared with friends in the UK.

The players issued swift apologies, but City, owned by the Thai billionaire Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha and his son Aiyawatt, sacked the three and restated their commitment to “promoting a positive message of community and family values and equality”.

Announcing the decision to sign the 22-year-old Smith, subject to a medical, the Northampton manager, Chris Wilder, acknowledged the deal would be controversial. He told the club website: “I’m aware this signing will create debate.

“Adam was involved in an incident at Leicester was very wrong and he knows that better than anyone. He paid a price for that, he has apologised and is ashamed of what happened.

“But we also live in a society where, as long as people show genuine remorse, admit their mistake, learn from it and apologise then they deserve a second chance. Adam knows that and he is determined to take this chance.

“He is a very good goalkeeper, and one who needs to be in and around a first team place to push himself forward and I am sure he will prove a good addition.”

Smith said: “I got myself in a situation I am deeply ashamed of, and I am desperately sorry for that. I know the club here do a lot of anti-racism work and have a proud record in that area and I am keen to help the club with that.

“I am really sorry for what I was involved in but I need to put that stupid mistake behind me. I am really grateful for the second chance I have been offered here and I am determined to make the most of it.”

cards.title: West Ham / Club complete £10.7m signing of Marseille forward Payet
cards.rawTitle: Club complete £10.7m signing of Marseille forward Payet

item.title: West Ham complete signing of Marseille forward Dimitri Payet
item.trailText: West Ham have signed the French international forward Dimitri Payet from Marseille on a five-year deal
item.standFirst:
• France international joins on five-year deal
• Payet has 15 caps and topped assist charts last season
item.body:
West Ham United have completed the signing of the Marseille forward Dimitri Payet for a fee believed to be £10.7m. The east London club announced on Friday afternoon that Payet, 28, has signed a five-year deal with a further one-year option and becomes the second major addition to the playing squad under their new manager, Slaven Bilic.

“West Ham really showed me that they wanted me to come, both the joint-chairmen [David Gold and David Sullivan] and the manager,” Payet told the club’s website.

“That’s very important for me. I was also keen to sign up to a clear project. West Ham’s is very interesting and matches perfectly with my ambitions.

“Firstly I spoke with the manager, who really wished for me to come here and had been watching me a lot. He made it clear that he wanted me to sign and that was important in my choice.

“I’m an attacking footballer and that they’re counting on me to help achieve that gives me a sense of responsibility. It’s true that it’s taken a little while but that’s normal – negotiations are like that. But now that it’s done, I’m very happy.”

The versatile Payet topped the Ligue 1 assist charts last season with 16 in 36 appearances, as well as scoring seven goals for a Marseille side who came fourth in Ligue 1 last season. He can play in a number of attacking positions, adding depth and variation to a frontline that was exposed by injuries and loss of form in the second half of last season.

Payet, who spent two seasons at Marseille after playing for Nantes, Saint-Étienne and Lille, has 15 caps for France and started in their most recent fixture, a 1-0 friendly defeat in Albania this month.

The arrival of Payet, who was born on the French island of Réunion in the Indian Ocean, follows that of the Sampdoria midfielder Pedro Obiang.

West Ham’s first match of the 2015-16 season is a Europa League first qualifying round, first-leg fixture against the Andorran side Lusitans on Thursday.

cards.title: Fifa / Blatter: ‘I did not resign … I’m not ready for the museum or a waxwork’
cards.rawTitle: Blatter: ‘I did not resign … I’m not ready for the museum or a waxwork’

item.title: Sepp Blatter: ‘I did not resign … I’m not ready for the museum or a waxwork’
item.trailText: Fifa has once again had to deny that Sepp Blatter may attempt to stay on at Fifa after remarks during his first public appearance since his announcement
item.standFirst:
• Fifa forced to stress that words are in line with previous remarks
• Comments come three weeks after he revealed plan to step down
item.body:
In what is becoming a regular pattern, Fifa has been forced to insist hurriedly that Sepp Blatter will not stand again for the presidency and will “lay down his mandate” as promised.

Blatter sparked a fresh wave of speculation when a Swiss newspaper reported him as saying: “I have not resigned, I put my mandate in the hands of an extraordinary congress.”

With a typically obtuse flourish, the 79-year-old added: “Only those who know the past can understand the present and shape the future. Or in other words: the ball is round – but only those who come from outer space know the actual dimensions of our sport … For me personally, the museum is a labour of love. But do not get me wrong: I’m not ready for the museum nor for a waxwork yet.”

Fifa said that his comments, at an event held at the Fifa museum in Zurich, were in line with his speech on 2 June when he did not mention resigning but did promise to lay down his mandate at an extraordinary congress between December and March.

In that same speech he said: “I shall not be a candidate,” and said the election, most likely in December, would be for his successor. Fifa insiders were quick to insist that he would not be standing again, despite the inevitable speculation that he might perform a U-turn given his history.

He said in 2011 that his fourth term as president would be his last, only to stand again in 2015 and win, before promising to step down four days later given the maelstrom engulfing Fifa as a result of twin US and Swiss criminal investigations.

The comments, and recent on-the -record quotes by his former adviser Klaus Stöhlker, are being viewed by many as an attempt to destabilise his opponents, including the Uefa president, Michel Platini.

Stöhlker, an adviser to Blatter during his re-election campaign, told the Guardian that Blatter would reconsider “if there was no other viable candidate” and that if he stood he would win.

The Fifa executive committee will meet on 20 July to decide a date for the extraordinary congress in what is expected to be the latest staging post in the politicking that has followed the dramatic events of late May, when 14 officials were charged in the US with a “World Cup of fraud” on counts of money-laundering, racketeering and fraud.

Fifa has yet to confirm whether Blatter and his secretary general, Jérôme Valcke, under pressure over what he knew about a $10m payment from South Africa to the Caribbean via Fifa that US investigators alleged was a bribe, would travel to Canada for the Women’s World Cup final, which takes place a week on Sunday. It had previously been forced to deny claims that Blatter was avoiding the US due to the continuing FBI investigation. “The travel plans of both the Fifa president and secretary general will be communicated in due course,” said a Fifa spokesman.

item.title: Fifa president Sepp Blatter’s attendance at Women’s World Cup final in doubt
item.trailText: Sepp Blatter’s attendance at the Women’s World Cup final in Canada next week appears to be in jeopardy due to the twin investigations into Fifa by American and Swiss justice authorities
item.standFirst:
• Blatter is due to present trophy at final in Vancouver
• Fifa spokesman would not confirm if president will travel to Canada
item.body:
Sepp Blatter’s attendance at the Women’s World Cup final in Canada next week appears to be in jeopardy due to the twin investigations into Fifa by American and Swiss justice authorities.

Blatter would normally attend the final and hand over the trophy to the captain of the winning team but Fifa will not confirm whether he or the secretary general, Jérôme Valcke, will attend.

A spokesperson said: “In terms of the Fifa president and the Fifa secretary general, their future travel plans will be confirmed in due course.”

Related: Russians expect Sepp Blatter to attend 2018 World Cup qualifying draw

Reports in the United States have said Blatter and Valcke are among those under investigation by the FBI, which has so far indicted 18 people on football-related corruption charges.

A source close to Fifa said the crisis is having a bearing over whether Blatter travels to Canada. The Swiss attorney general is also investigating the bidding process for the 2018 and 2022 World Cups.

Neither the president nor secretary general have been charged with any wrongdoing and the US has not requested Blatter’s or Valcke’s extradition. Should that change, as a Swiss national Blatter is protected from extradition from Switzerland by Article 7 of IMAC, the governing Swiss law.

The Russian sports minister, Vitaly Mutko, has said Blatter will attend the 2018 World Cup qualifying draw in St Petersburg on 25 July.

“Of course, he will attend the draw,” Mutko said on Tuesday. “The whole of the Fifa executive committee will be there as well as all 209 national federations. Preparations are going as planned.”
